title: Ticket #2132: [Debian] Using shared libraries
description:
For being accepted as a Debian package, Condor should build using shared libraries. This ticket is for the respective patch already created by Michael.

Changes impact CMake files.

Branch V7_7-debian-publicbranch in the git repository contains changes for this ticket.
remarks:
2011-May-13 11:25:29 by tstclair:
Note, this will need to be an option enabled function (Windows will not build shared libs without exports) and should be hidden under a macro so higher level functionality is not impacted.

2011-May-17 08:33:29 by bbockelm:
Any updates on this? I'm building a new release for our site, and I'd like to include this patch.

2011-May-19 14:41:39 by cat:
[Originally, I sent this note as email to the CC list, but now that I have access to the wiki again, I am posting it as a remark for posterity.]

Of all of the Debian-related patches that we are working to integrate, this one will take the longest. It is the most complex and has some fairly broad implications.

Are you building Condor from source for your site? If so, out of curiosity: Why? And why do you want to include the shared-library patch for your site? What makes this change compelling for you?

2011-May-19 14:52:35 by tstclair:
Deployment is the most obvious reason. It reduces the thunk from ~300+ MB >50.

Multiply that by thousands of machines == good motivation.

2011-May-19 15:23:13 by matt:
Please attach the patch to this ticket so we can see what's being discussed.

2011-May-19 16:44:06 by cweiss:
As agreed in an earlier meeting, all these changes go into a separate branch to avoid patch chaos. So just take a look at the associated commit.

2011-Nov-02 14:55:57 by jfrey:
All of the Condor utility libraries are now one large library, named condor_utils. On linux and mac, this is a shared library. On other platforms, it's static. The shared library is unversioned and, for vendor packaging, is kept in a 'condor' subdirectory.
